ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Mastered calculus
math skills
I developed skills about thinking outside of the box when solving problems.
I developed the ability to integrate various functions, determine converge or diverge of multiple series and calculate the volume of rotational solids.
I believe that I have learned how to properly study for a STEM class. I did not know how much effort I would have to put in, but with the help of professors, it made the course easier.

I learned a lot about how the concepts in Calc 2 connect to real-life examples, especially through the Explorations because they explained the concepts in ways that they could be nderstood more logically rather than conceptually.

Since the course was so cumulative, I made sure that my understanding of a given topic was solid before allowing myself to move on. If I had any questions or confusion about a topic, I made sure to seek help so that I would not continue on with the course on a shaky foundation. This mindset is valuable for all my courses.

I learned how to find integrals, determine convergence/divergence, differentiate sequences vs. series, find volumes of revolution...
It is a great fundamental course for calculus, and the course progresses in a logical manner.
I learned how to take integrals and find the solutions to some series.

I learned how to do math fast. It was a necessity in this course to be able to whiz through problems without much of a thought as to "what is this?" It wasn't satisfying, but it got the job done. And I do understand that part of math is turning computations into muscle memory. This class did that.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Its a pretty great course tbh
Strengths - office hour/tutoring opportunities
I think it could be improved if all classes had information packets. I know some classes received them and others did not.
I appreciate how the course was taught in a seminaresque style, which allowed accessing the professor easier. The class size was also appropriate.

An overall weakness is the difficulty of the problem sets. They are much harder than the questions asked in class and harder than what appears on the exam. It makes doing them cumbersome and frustrating. One thing I liked was the explores.
Strengths were online resources available and the practice tests. Weaknesses were that some lectures were not helpful.
The explorations on Canvas are very helpful to learning the material, but they only explain the surface level concepts and its harder to answer more in-depth questions.

I liked the exposure to the material I received through the explore activities; I think those were more helpful to my understanding of the topics than I realized. Furthermore, the peer tutoring resources, review sessions before the exams, and access to practice exams were all very helpful. I never felt like I had a lack of support while learning the material.

Strengths:
The course was well-designed, not leaving any conspicuous gaps of knowledge for students.
The problem sets assigned by the course were also sufficiently challenging and helped me prepare for the test.
By setting numerous smaller deadlines, the course encouraged students to review often and retain their knowledge.

Weaknesses:
Course material is not the most interesting, but this is not the professor's fault. Probably mostly my fault actually.

The problem sets were often more difficult than the exam questions, so they prepare you well for the exams. Peer tutoring is very helpful when working through problem sets, so the problem sets are not too overwhelming if you get the help you may need. With the class not being a large lecture, there are not class recordings, so you have to make sure to take thorough notes in class. The class can feel long, so it can sometimes be difficult to stay engaged and diligent with notes.
I would say I am pretty solid on this topic, although I could benefit from practicing the theoretical.

Strengths: The order in which concepts were presented was logical, coherent, and beneficial to my understanding. I
Weaknesses: The quantity of content eclipsed the quality of learning.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely
I definitely recommend this course to anyone considering a STEM major.
I would recommend this course to another student. The problem sets are published in advance so doing the work is straight forward and its quite manageable.
If they need to take it, then yes. However it is not an enjoyable class they should look to take if they do not need a requirement.
Yes, it is a requirement for many STEM majors and it is a fair class for the workload.
Yes, if you put the time into going to tutoring and asking for help, I think anyone could thrive in this course.
Yes I would recommend the course. I believe that there are many resources provided to the students that help us succeed.
Only if it's a requirement

Whether if one is taking this for their major or quantitative reasoning requirement, I think MATH 115 is a pretty good course to take. It is what you would expect, but you get a lot of resources outside the classroom on Canvas, with Office Hours, and review sessions. I wouldn't take this course for fun though.

Yes, I would recommend this course especially if you are only in need of one calculus course. Even if you did not take calc BC in high school, you should be able to do well in the course without feeling far behind. As long as you have a general understanding of calc 1, you can work your way through this course.
I feel like this course greatly changes with the professor you get. I would recommend my professor.

I would recommend this course to another student, so long as they were willing to treat these difficult subjects with the same respect and dedication that they would treat the grammar rules of a new language. It also helps if you have an innate interest in the conceptual significance of calculus. But that has to come from within when taking this course, because in my experience, it was not part of the class experience. In fact, I was constantly trying to remind myself why I used to love math.
